    AddWithHttpMessagesAsync(PoolAddParameter, PoolAddOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    AddWithHttpMessagesAsync(PoolAddParameter, PoolAddOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Adds a pool to the specified account.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolAddHeaders>> AddWithHttpMessagesAsync(PoolAddParameter pool, PoolAddOptions poolAddOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function AddWithHttpMessagesAsync(pool As PoolAddParameter, poolAddOptions As PoolAddOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolAddHeaders))

    Parameters

    • pool
      PoolAddParameter
      PoolAddParameter

      The pool to be added.

    • poolAddOptions
      PoolAddOptions
      PoolAddOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolAddHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolAddHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    When naming pools, avoid including sensitive information such as user names or secret project names. This information may appear in telemetry logs accessible to Microsoft Support engineers.

  • Edit
    DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolDeleteOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolDeleteOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Deletes a pool from the specified account.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolDeleteHeaders>> DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, PoolDeleteOptions poolDeleteOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function DeleteWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, poolDeleteOptions As PoolDeleteOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolDeleteHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool to delete.

    • poolDeleteOptions
      PoolDeleteOptions
      PoolDeleteOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolDeleteHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolDeleteHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    When you request that a pool be deleted, the following actions occur: the pool state is set to deleting; any ongoing resize operation on the pool are stopped; the Batch service starts resizing the pool to zero nodes; any tasks running on existing nodes are terminated and requeued (as if a resize pool operation had been requested with the default requeue option); finally, the pool is removed from the system. Because running tasks are requeued, the user can rerun these tasks by updating their job to target a different pool. The tasks can then run on the new pool. If you want to override the requeue behavior, then you should call resize pool explicitly to shrink the pool to zero size before deleting the pool. If you call an Update, Patch or Delete API on a pool in the deleting state, it will fail with HTTP status code 409 with error code PoolBeingDeleted.

    EnableAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter, PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    EnableAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter, PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Enables automatic scaling for a pool.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolEnableAutoScaleHeaders>> EnableAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter poolEnableAutoScaleParameter, PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions poolEnableAutoScaleOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function EnableAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, poolEnableAutoScaleParameter As PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter, poolEnableAutoScaleOptions As PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolEnableAutoScaleHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool on which to enable automatic scaling.

    • poolEnableAutoScaleParameter
      PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter
      PoolEnableAutoScaleParameter

      The parameters for the request.

    • poolEnableAutoScaleOptions
      PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions
      PoolEnableAutoScaleOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolEnableAutoScaleHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolEnableAutoScaleHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    You cannot enable automatic scaling on a pool if a resize operation is in progress on the pool. If automatic scaling of the pool is currently disabled, you must specify a valid autoscale formula as part of the request. If automatic scaling of the pool is already enabled, you may specify a new autoscale formula and/or a new evaluation interval. You cannot call this API for the same pool more than once every 30 seconds.

    EvaluateAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, String, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    EvaluateAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, String, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Gets the result of evaluating an automatic scaling formula on the pool.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationResponse<AutoScaleRun, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleHeaders>> EvaluateAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, string autoScaleFormula, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions poolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function EvaluateAutoScaleWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, autoScaleFormula As String, poolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions As PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationResponse(Of AutoScaleRun, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool on which to evaluate the automatic scaling formula.

    • autoScaleFormula
      String
      String

      The formula for the desired number of compute nodes in the pool. The formula is validated and its results calculated, but it is not applied to the pool. To apply the formula to the pool, 'Enable automatic scaling on a pool'. For more information about specifying this formula, see Automatically scale compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool (https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/batch-automatic-scaling).

    • poolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions
      PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions
      PoolEvaluateAutoScaleOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationResponse<AutoScaleRun, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationResponse(Of AutoScaleRun, PoolEvaluateAutoScaleHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    This API is primarily for validating an autoscale formula, as it simply returns the result without applying the formula to the pool.

      String

    Exceptions

    Remarks

    This operation can only run when the allocation state of the pool is steady. When this operation runs, the allocation state changes from steady to resizing.

  • Edit
    ResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolResizeParameter, PoolResizeOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    ResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolResizeParameter, PoolResizeOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Changes the number of compute nodes that are assigned to a pool.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolResizeHeaders>> ResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, PoolResizeParameter poolResizeParameter, PoolResizeOptions poolResizeOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function ResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, poolResizeParameter As PoolResizeParameter, poolResizeOptions As PoolResizeOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolResizeHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool to resize.

    • poolResizeParameter
      PoolResizeParameter
      PoolResizeParameter

      The parameters for the request.

    • poolResizeOptions
      PoolResizeOptions
      PoolResizeOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolResizeHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolResizeHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    You can only resize a pool when its allocation state is steady. If the pool is already resizing, the request fails with status code

    1. When you resize a pool, the pool's allocation state changes from steady to resizing. You cannot resize pools which are configured for automatic scaling. If you try to do this, the Batch service returns an error 409. If you resize a pool downwards, the Batch service chooses which nodes to remove. To remove specific nodes, use the pool remove nodes API instead.
  • Edit
    StopResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolStopResizeOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    StopResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, PoolStopResizeOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Stops an ongoing resize operation on the pool.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolStopResizeHeaders>> StopResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, PoolStopResizeOptions poolStopResizeOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function StopResizeWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, poolStopResizeOptions As PoolStopResizeOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolStopResizeHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool whose resizing you want to stop.

    • poolStopResizeOptions
      PoolStopResizeOptions
      PoolStopResizeOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolStopResizeHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolStopResizeHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    This does not restore the pool to its previous state before the resize operation: it only stops any further changes being made, and the pool maintains its current state. A resize operation need not be an explicit resize pool request; this API can also be used to halt the initial sizing of the pool when it is created.

  • Edit

      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    This fully replaces all the updateable properties of the pool. For example, if the pool has a start task associated with it and if start task is not specified with this request, then the Batch service will remove the existing start task.

  • Edit
    UpgradeOSWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, String, PoolUpgradeOSOptions, Dictionary<String, List<String>>, CancellationToken)
    UpgradeOSWithHttpMessagesAsync(String, String, PoolUpgradeOSOptions, Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)), CancellationToken)

    Upgrades the operating system of the specified pool.

    Task<Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolUpgradeOSHeaders>> UpgradeOSWithHttpMessagesAsync(string poolId, string targetOSVersion, PoolUpgradeOSOptions poolUpgradeOSOptions = null, Dictionary<string, List<string>> customHeaders = null, CancellationToken cancellationToken = null)Function UpgradeOSWithHttpMessagesAsync(poolId As String, targetOSVersion As String, poolUpgradeOSOptions As PoolUpgradeOSOptions = Nothing, customHeaders As Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String)) = Nothing, cancellationToken As CancellationToken = Nothing) As Task(Of Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolUpgradeOSHeaders))

    Parameters

    • poolId
      String
      String

      The ID of the pool to upgrade.

    • targetOSVersion
      String
      String

      The Azure Guest OS version to be installed on the virtual machines in the pool.

    • poolUpgradeOSOptions
      PoolUpgradeOSOptions
      PoolUpgradeOSOptions

      Additional parameters for the operation

    • customHeaders
      Dictionary<String, List<String>>
      Dictionary(Of String, List(Of String))

      The headers that will be added to request.

    • cancellationToken
      CancellationToken
      CancellationToken

      The cancellation token.

    Returns

    • Task<Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse<PoolUpgradeOSHeaders>>
      Task(Of Microsoft.Rest.Azure.AzureOperationHeaderResponse(Of PoolUpgradeOSHeaders))

    Exceptions

    • BatchErrorException
      BatchErrorException

      Thrown when the operation returned an invalid status code

    Remarks

    During an upgrade, the Batch service upgrades each compute node in the pool. When a compute node is chosen for upgrade, any tasks running on that node are removed from the node and returned to the queue to be rerun later (or on a different compute node). The node will be unavailable until the upgrade is complete. This operation results in temporarily reduced pool capacity as nodes are taken out of service to be upgraded. Although the Batch service tries to avoid upgrading all compute nodes at the same time, it does not guarantee to do this (particularly on small pools); therefore, the pool may be temporarily unavailable to run tasks. When this operation runs, the pool state changes to upgrading. When all compute nodes have finished upgrading, the pool state returns to active.
